Exploring variation in articulatory setting in New Zealand English using Facial Tracking

Joshua Wilson Black
joshua.black@canterbury.ac.nz

Te KƒÅhui Roro Reo | New Zealand Institute of Language, Brain and Behaviour

Te Whare WƒÅnanga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury

Overview

Overview

  1. Articulatory setting
  2. Face tracking
  3. Variation in (1) via (2)

Articulatory setting

Definitions

  • Originally defined for languages (Honikman 1964)
    • A disposition of the speech mechanism and its actions which produces ‚Äònatural‚Äô speech.
    • Distinguish: ‚Äòinternal‚Äô vs ‚Äòexternal‚Äô
    • External articulatory setting can be studied by observing films across languages.
  • Part of Honikman‚Äôs idea: ‚ÄúA language‚Äôs underlying articulatory posture‚Äù (Wilson and Gick 2014)
    • ‚Ä¶but dispositions to certain kinds of motion also included.
    • Distinguish: ‚Äòstatic‚Äô vs ‚Äòdynamic‚Äô

Measuring articulatory setting

  • Challenge: distinguishing articulatory setting from articulation of individual speech segments.
  • Wilson and Gick (2014) use ultrasounds from bilinguals who are perceived to sound ‚Äònative‚Äô in both languages and show that they use distinct articulatory settings for each.
  • Key move: measure interspeech posture, i.e., the position of the articulators ‚Äòwhen they are motionless during interutterance pauses‚Äô.
  • Misses ‚Äòdynamic‚Äô features.

In sociolinguistics

  • Why not variation within languages?
  • Pratt and D‚ÄôOnofrio (2017)
    • Jaw setting of actors when pretending to be Californians vs. non-Californians.
    • Method: audio and video from parodic performance (‚ÄúThe Californians‚Äù series of SNL sketches)
    • Analysis of frequency of lip protrusion and vocalic production.
    • Suggestion that features of California Vowel Shift come with adoption of articulatory setting (open jaw + lip protrusion).

In sociolinguistics (2)

  • (Holmes-Elliott and Levon 2024)
    • Vowel centralisation in modern RP explained by adoption of ‚Äòlax voice‚Äô
    • i.e. neutral tongue and little movement of articulators (incl. jaw)
    • Analysis compares speech from The Only Way is Essex (modern Cockney) and Made in Chelsea (modern RP).
  • Claim: lax voice is a way of embodying elite status and may function across English varieties (incl. California example)

Noise or signal?

  • Articulatory settings have systematic effects on the vowel space.
  • Relatedly: amplitude variation affects first formant readings, across the board (Wilson Black et al. 2023).
    • ‚Ä¶possibly driven by jaw height variation
  • Noise if driven by variation in speaker fatigue?
  • Signal if adoption of socially meaningful posture?
  • Answers are project dependent.

  • This project treats articulatory setting variation as signal.
    • ‚Ä¶but getting a handle on the variation is important in either case.

Face tracking

Describing video of speech at scale

  • Honikman (1964) and Pratt and D‚ÄôOnofrio (2017) describe features of speech in video and, in the latter case, code it to analyse relative frequencies.
  • But can we scale up this kind of analysis?
  • Contemporary facial landmark detection algorithms offer one possibility.

Google MediaPipe

  • Google MediaPipe set of machine learning tools to run on-device
    • i.e., they don‚Äôt rely on cloud services.

  • MediaPipe Face Landmarker takes images or video and returns ‚Äòface landmarks‚Äô and then ‚Äòblendshape coefficients‚Äô
  • Face detection ‚á® Face mesh (478 landmarks) ‚á® Blendshape prediction (57 shapes)

Blendshape coefficients

  • 57 ‚Äòshapes‚Äô which are intended to capture facial expressions.
    • e.g. mouthFrownLeft, noseSneerLeft, mouthFunnel, jawOpen, eyeSquintRight, eyeWideLeft‚Ä¶
  • Created by Apple for augmented reality applications (see here)
  • Sometimes used for animating 3D avatars

Meet our model

AI-assisted development of an initial (non-working) demo (I don‚Äôt know javascript!)

Blendshapes ‚á® articulatory setting

  • Overarching RQ: Can blendshape coefficients be used to track external articulatory setting?
  • More specific: Add ‚Äúwithin a language variety‚Äù
    • Can we find meaningful across-speaker variation in blendshape values during interspeech pauses (a la Wilson and Gick 2014),
    • or in variation in blendshape parameters during speech (a la Holmes-Elliott and Levon 2024)?
  • Even more specific: Replace ‚Äúwithin a language variety‚Äù with ‚Äúcontemporary New Zealand English‚Äù

Articulatory setting variation via face tracking in NZE

Data

  • Source: the subset of QuakeBox in the LaBB-CAT public demo corpus
    • Future plans: Apply this analysis to the full QB corpus.
  • Full corpus has 587 participants (Clark et al. 2016)
  • Non-NZ speakers will remain while establishing the steps from video to interspeech pauses.
  • Currently only 16 speakers have face tracking applied.

Video ‚á® blendshapes

  • QuakeBox has audio and video stored on a LaBB-CAT instance (Fromont and Hay 2012).
  • Video is run through MediaPipe on the LaBB-CAT instance.
  • Blendshapes are stored as layers in each transcript (one for each frame).
  • Blendshape coefficients extracted via nzilbb.labbcat R package.
    • Start and end time vary by analysis.

Analysis 1: Interspeech posture

  • Recall: interspeech posture (ISP) is the position of the articulators ‚Äòwhen they are motionless during interutterance pauses‚Äô (Wilson and Gick 2014).
  • ‚ÄòInterutterance pauses‚Äô: get blendshape coefficients between end of last word start of first word in following utterance.
  • Future stress test: why not use pauses within utterances? We know where they are.

Pause lengths

Figure 1: Distribution of pause lengths.

  • Filter pauses longer than 2 seconds (675 ‚Üí 645)

‚ÄòMotionless‚Äô?

  • Wilson and Gick (2014) require 10 frames of video without tongue movement.
  • This will not work for us, but we can:
    1. limit co-articulation effects by ditching the first and last 10%
    2. filter right tail of mean absolute change of jawOpen (+2.5sd).

Face PCA

  • PCA is a standard technique for investigating structural covariation when you have a lot of variables.
  • Previous work on NZE has used PCA to capture covariation in the vowel system.
  • At this (exploratory) stage:
    1. Apply PCA to mean blendshape coefficient during ISP(ish) for each speaker, and
    2. visualise variation using our 3D avatar.

Face PCA results

Hints

Hints

Future plans

  • More stress testing of key assumptions, e.g.:
    • How normalised are blendshape coefficients really?
  • Continue to implement on full QuakeBox corpus.
  • Interpret with respect to existing acoustic work.
  • Look at dynamic features of articulatory setting:
    • esp. jaw height variation both within and across speakers.
